channel.title: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)
channel.description:
Its simple, if you have the 1.5.06 of the jre all your runtime classes are in rt.jar, along with the precious math.class with its random() function, so I extracted and decompiled math.class and made the random() method return a constant (0.3), then compiled and with winrar overwrote the old math.class
when running runescape, the flames dont look right, and colors on the main screen along with color and location of the mm symbols never change, even if you close the client and open another one, the road color however still changes randomly, so one must assume it is sent from the server (they arent using java.util.random because I also edited that entire class to return constant values, yet they still change)
here I am attaching my edited math.class and math.java, you simply have to open rt.jar (located in your java/lib folder) with winrar, navigate to java/lang/ and replace the old math.class with this math.class (wouldnt hurt to keep a backup)
(this has gotta be the dirtiest of dirtiest hacks, but eh, whatever works)
one last thing: do you think this is very detectable? also should we keep it from the general population so jagex doesnt make all colors controlled serverside or not? post opinions :)

item.title: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Ruler, perhaps you should look for yourself. Maybe you might accomplish something good worth mentioning.

Read full topic
item.source: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)

item.title: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote="Krichevskoy, post:37, topic:3200"][quote author=ruler link=topic=3710.msg36784#msg36784 date=1148438245]
My idea...

if(Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace()[stack.length - 1].getClassName().equals(????)){
   return 0.3;
}

[/quote]

Not with this new obfuscation you won't. Not only do the class names change, the actual location of x piece of code or whatever variable could be in a different class altogether in the next version (there are some consistent classes, but it looks like there might be certain methods designated as 'floating' that get relocated; also variables are insanely scrambled across the board). In order to locate it you would have to at least analyse the client, which defeats the purpose of a meta-client hack in the first place.

[quote author=Pwnd link=topic=3710.msg37255#msg37255 date=1148527434]
Could you reroute it so the random value is sent and the consisten value is used in the client? Might be harder than it sounds.
[/quote]

Don't know if you remember when wunderlesser started posting tutorials on using javassist, but this was exactly what one of them did to lock the minimap (of course, no source required). The only problem with it now is that the random polling might catch your new variable (I haven't really looked into it beyond the fact that it exists, so I'm not sure if it only checks vars Jagex knows are there).[/quote]
well yes, you would need to update this with every rs update, mebe the stacksize is always the same? patterns, ect?

Read full topic
item.source: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)

item.title: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

[quote="ruler, post:20, topic:3200"]My idea...

if(Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace()[stack.length - 1].getClassName().equals(????)){
   return 0.3;
}

[/quote]

Not with this new obfuscation you won't. Not only do the class names change, the actual location of x piece of code or whatever variable could be in a different class altogether in the next version (there are some consistent classes, but it looks like there might be certain methods designated as 'floating' that get relocated; also variables are insanely scrambled across the board). In order to locate it you would have to at least analyse the client, which defeats the purpose of a meta-client hack in the first place.

Pwnd:

Could you reroute it so the random value is sent and the consisten value is used in the client? Might be harder than it sounds.

Don't know if you remember when wunderlesser started posting tutorials on using javassist, but this was exactly what one of them did to lock the minimap (of course, no source required). The only problem with it now is that the random polling might catch your new variable (I haven't really looked into it beyond the fact that it exists, so I'm not sure if it only checks vars Jagex knows are there).

Read full topic

item.title: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

xSignal:

Well, this is safer at the moment. But if we did client editing when we knew about the engine, client editing would be safer

Actually, I'm going to go with client editing as safer right now. Here's one example:
There are several variables associated with the minimap that are initialized to something like

int minimap1 = (int)(Math.random() * 120D) - 30;

If you look at some methods functionally associated with minimap walking, you'll notice that these variables are sent to the server along with your click coordinates. What is Jagex to think when your minimap1 variable consistently equals 6?

Read full topic

moparisthebest:

hmm sine you say ill make math.sine() return a constant value and see what happens

nope, still random, so it must be sent from the server like was stated before

xSignal:

Very clever, yet highly detectable, as RegeX said.
Probably client editing would be safer.

could be detectable, but definatly safer than client editing

@WT-Fakawi wrote:

[SCAR]Not sure if this appropriate here, but after solving the serverside RoadColor problem yesterday, I ran my Draynor Melter (unsigned, to make sure I get lots of different RoadColors... no cache). It walks from Draynor to Lumbridge, melts anything, walks back and banks ad infin.... I logged all the changing RoadColors, and I noticed a waving pattern. They dont change randomly but they inc/dec in sinusoidal movements[/SCAR]

item.title: Remove Random color changing (ran from runescape.com, no java edits)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Teh Freak:

This idea is rather old, i remember when RANCID posted about it on rscn forums ages ago, and the question came up whether to edit the class or not, i remember someone implying that it may be detectable, but who knows. Im not sure about the idea, because if you have a few random()'s, you should at least have an array of like 5 ints to return, even if they're just .1,.2,.3,.4,.5 seeing as how it wouldnt really make much of a difference in colors anyways for rs. but thats just me.

that was back before my time rofl, but yea I was thinking of making a new class that would give you somthing like a constant random number to use for each instance of the jvm, so like the colors would stay the same while you had rs loaded, but would change when you closed it and reloaded it, but it seems like a waste of my time
